results.title: Memory's voice: capturing stories of courage
results.brief_description: Undertaken in partnership with Alzheimer’s Australia, Vic Memory’s Voice captures the stories of ten people impacted by dementia. These powerful stories examine the complexities of the condition ‘ the losses, the adjustments and the need to move forward ‘ preserving the spirit of the families involved and creating life long tributes to personal achievement.
results.description: Undertaken in partnership with Alzheimer’s Australia, Vic Memory’s Voice captures the stories of ten people impacted by dementia. results.title: Passionate pursuits
results.brief_description: This story was created for Robin Hodder’s grandchildren to celebrate his extraordinary achievements as an Olympic sportsman, a husband of 38 years and the world’s greatest dad. Created as part of the ‘Memory’s Voice: Capturing Stories of Courage’ workshop, an ACMI Digital Storytelling Project in association with Alzheimer’s Australia Vic and in partnership with VicHealth.

group.title: Memory's voice: capturing stories of courage

results.title: Max and Noel Oliver's story
results.brief_description:
Alzheimer’s sufferer Max together with his wife Noel have told a story for their granddaughters that celebrates their life together as well as capturing Max’s memories of his son, the children’s father, who died when they were very young. Created as part of the ‘Memory’s Voice: Capturing Stories of Courage’ workshop, an ACMI Digital Storytelling Project in association with Alzheimer’s Australia Vic and in partnership with VicHealth.
You can create your own Digital Story. Ask at the Information Desk or visit www.acmi.net.au/digitalstorytelling

group.title: Memory's voice: capturing stories of courage

results.title: Carmel: storyteller
results.brief_description: Carmel is a retired school teacher, wife, mother and grandmother. Her family’ s life dramatically changed when she was diagnosed with early onset memory loss. With her husband, she tells their story and looks positively in the face of an unknown future. Created as part of the ‘Memory’s Voice: Capturing Stories of Courage’ workshop, an ACMI Digital Storytelling Project in association with Alzheimer’s Australia Vic and in partnership with VicHealth.

group.title: Memory's voice: capturing stories of courage

results.title: Harvey
results.creator_credit: Rachel Roberts, Priscilla Collins, Peter McDonald and AFTRS
results.brief_description: Peter McDonald’s Harvey takes the notion of ‘finding your other half’ to its logical and very gory conclusion. In stark black and white, a woman is spied on by an unseen man who lives in the apartment across from her. When the woman falls in the shower and is knocked unconscious, the man takes this opportunity to finally reveal his true, mangled self. Cast features Nicholas Hope as Harvey and Lisa Angove as Lily.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Rachel Roberts, Priscilla Collins, Peter McDonald and AFTRS

results.title: Dummy
results.brief_description: Pregnant with absence, ‘Dummy’ depicts desolate urban and suburban environments. Filmed in and around Melbourne, these everyday, expectant spaces are captured with formal elegance and an accidental beauty that reveals a unique insight into the secret and forgotten life of Melbourne.

results.title: Nice time
results.brief_description: An observation of couples and youths at night around London’s famous Piccadilly Circus. Influenced by the Free Cinema movement, Claude Goretta and Alain Tanner allow the camera to observe the scenes of people milling in front of cinemas, walking around the Circle and attempting to get into night clubs. There is no voice over, and instead, it is the observational mise-en-scene and the almost relaxed detachment of the observing camera that creates a leisurely but intriguing glimpse into everyday pleasure and life. The decision of the Swiss directors, Goretta and Tanner, to travel to the UK to involve themselves in Free Cinema was an indication of the immense influence the movement was having on documentary filmmaking, an influence that was to lead to the radical aesthetics of “cinema verite”.

results.title: Momma don't allow
results.brief_description: This early key work by Karel Reisz and Tony Richardson follows a group of young English men and women going out and exploring the jazz clubs of London. Made as part of the Free Cinema documentary movement, Momma Don’t Allow is observational rather than didactic, capturing the joy and pleasure of music, going out and being part of a gang.

results.title: Synthing
results.brief_description: Synthing is the result of years of exploratory work across disciplines. “The Synthing concept puts expressive and energetic body movement in front of a video camera interface to create an engrossing interplay of music and images within the framework of a cybermedium… a synaesthetic compositional tool”, says Gruchy. Synthing, through its use of real-time navigation and interactive technologies, allows real opportunities for audience interaction.

results.title: Expectant spaces
results.brief_description: A commissioned Public Imaging project by Melbourne cinematographer, Ben Speth. His extraordinary, meditative work manifests as a mysterious visual documentation of volume, light and time in deserted urban spaces. A sense of expectancy emerges through his still, ghostly and enigmatic images of spaces of waiting or anticipation - hospital emergency rooms, bus shelters, classrooms, dental waiting rooms, car parks.
